title_en: Systematically Maps the 'Fraunhofer Lines' (Solar Absorption Spectrum)

summary.text_en: Joseph von Fraunhofer, a master optician, independently rediscovered (after Wollaston) that the solar spectrum was not continuous but was crossed by thousands of 'dark lines'. He was observing the sun with a high-quality prism and an instrument he invented: the 'spectroscope'. His great contribution was to *systematically* measure and map the precise location of ~570 of these lines, labeling the most prominent ones with letters (A through K). These 'Fraunhofer lines' are the sun's 'absorption spectrum'.
key_points_en: Mapped the 'dark lines' (absorption spectrum) of the Sun
Provided the key data for spectroscopy (`bunsen_spectroscopy_1859`)

story.text_en: Fraunhofer's goal was not pure science; it was to build *perfect* telescopes. He needed a pure, single-color light source to precisely measure the 'refractive index' of his glass to eliminate chromatic aberration ('color fringing'). When he passed sunlight through his high-quality prism, instead of a smooth rainbow, he saw a 'barcode' of dark, missing stripes. He didn't ignore these 'flaws'; he mapped them with incredible precision. He didn't know *what* they were, but he provided the 'treasure map' that later scientists (Kirchhoff and Bunsen) would use to 'decode' the chemical composition of the Sun.

fun_facts.text_en: Fraunhofer also observed the spectrum of a sodium flame in his lab and saw it emitted two bright 'yellow lines'. He noted they were in the *exact same position* as the dark 'D-line' he had mapped in the sun's spectrum.
The English scientist William Wollaston had seen a few of the dark lines in 1802, but he dismissed them as 'natural boundaries' between the colors.

simple_explanation.text_en: Imagine thinking a rainbow was a 'complete' band of color. Fraunhofer was the first person to look at it in 'high-resolution' (with a spectroscope) and say, 'Wait, there are hundreds of 'gaps' in the rainbow!' The sunlight was like a punch-card with specific colors *missing*. He didn't know why, but he drew a precise map of all the 'holes'. This map *is* the Fraunhofer Lines, and it became the key to figuring out what stars are made of.

applications.text_en: The lines gave opticians 'standard reference wavelengths' (like the 'D-line') to precisely measure and standardize the refractive index of glass.

impact.text_en: Fraunhofer turned Newton's 'spectrum' (a beautiful phenomenon) into a *measurable dataset* that contained hidden information. Though he didn't crack the code, his precise map was the absolute prerequisite for Kirchhoff and Bunsen to found 'spectroscopy'. Spectroscopy, in turn, led to astrochemistry and provided the core experimental evidence for Niels Bohr's quantum model of the atom (`bohr_atom_1913`).

influenced_by.contribution_en: Newton (whose work with prisms splitting white light was the foundation for Fraunhofer)

influenced.contribution_en: Bunsen & Kirchhoff (their spectroscopy was created to *explain* the Fraunhofer lines)
Kirchhoff (his law of radiation explained *how* the Fraunhofer lines formed as an absorption spectrum)
Niels Bohr (his atomic model finally explained *physically* why the lines appear at those *specific* locations)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Fraunhofer was the 'fingerprint-taker' of the Sun. The map he drew became the Rosetta Stone for decoding the chemistry of the stars.

quiz.question_en: What do the 'dark lines' (Fraunhofer lines) that Fraunhofer found in the Sun's spectrum represent?
options_en: Specific colors of light 'absorbed' by cooler chemical elements in the Sun's atmosphere
quiz.explanation_en: The dark lines are an 'absorption spectrum'. The Sun's hot core emits a *full* rainbow, but as that light passes through the Sun's *cooler* outer atmosphere, chemical elements (like hydrogen and sodium) 'absorb' their own specific favorite colors, leaving 'gaps' (dark lines) in the rainbow.
